div1.p: [Peabody] informs Mallock of various projects, including a film strip on Walter Reed and a newspaper story on Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from [James E. Peabody] to [s.n.] Mallock, July 8, 1927
div1.opener:
The Morris High School
166TH ST. AND BOSTON ROAD
NEW YORK CITY
----o----
ELMER E. BOGART, PRINCIPAL
JAMES E. PEABODY
HEAD OF THE DEPARTMENT OF BIOLOGY
93 Carhart Avenue,
White Plains, N. Y.,
July 8, 1927.
My dear Miss Mallock:
div1.p:
I have just returned from New York, where I had a confer-
ence with Dr. Armstrong and Miss Franklin of the Metropolitan
Life Insurance Co. As you doubtless know they are preparing a
film strip to accompany the pamphlet you wrote for them on Wal-
ter Reed. At Mrs. Reed's suggestion I left with them all the
pictures she sent me, some of which they are to use.

While in the City I went to the Seripps-Howard Newspaper
Syndicate. They had asked me to tell them of the work we have
been carrying on for Kissinger, and they are very eager to is-
sue a series of articles with the aim of bringing about that
long-deferred Congressional action. Their representative, Miss
Saunders will prepare the articles as soon as I am ready.

In the meantime I am writing up a lecture on “The Conquest
of Yellow Fever” to accompany sets of lantern slides which we
hope will be rather widely used heres in the City Schools (under
the direction of the Museum of Natural History), and on the
Pacific Coast (under Dr. Hunter's direction. As soon as this
lecture is completed I plan to talk with the Metropolitan peo-
ple and with Miss Saunders. I shall place at their disposal any
pictures and other material in my possession, unless you think
that would interfere with your plans for the book you are to
write. It had seemed to me that all four of these lines of
activity are rather independent of each other, and could be
made mutually helpful.

I am wondering, therefore, if it would be convenient for
you to come to the Metropolitan Building about the middle of
this month. I am to have there my set of lantern slides, and
they have a lantern. Would you favor the plan of asking Miss
Saunders and Miss Franklin to join us, or would it be better
for me to see you first? My one desire now is to get that
pension bill through Congress early in December.

Did I write you of the very interesting series of letters
I have been getting from Margaret Deland (author of “Old Chester
Tales”? She is deeply interested in our campaign. She has invi-
ed Mrs. Peabody and me to her home to discuss ways and means.
